qas.question: Along with Miami Springs, where is the highest point of the Biscayne Aquifer?
The Biscayne Aquifer stretches from Palm Beach County to where?
After digging how many meters is one sure to reach running water in Miami?
What is limited by Miami's high water table?
Along with Miami Springs, where is the lowest point of the Biscayne Aquifer?
The Biscayne Aquifer stretches from Palm Beach County to when?
After digging how many meters is one not sure to reach running water in Miami?
After digging how many meters is one sure to reach running oil in Miami?
What is unlimited by Miami's high water table?

context: Beneath the plain lies the Biscayne Aquifer, a natural underground source of fresh water that extends from southern Palm Beach County to <a1_0><b5_0>Florida Bay<b5_0/><a1_0/>, with its highest point peaking around the cities of Miami Springs and <a0_0><b4_0>Hialeah<b4_0/><a0_0/>. Most of the Miami metropolitan area obtains its drinking water from this aquifer. As a result of the aquifer, it is not possible to dig more than 15 to 20 ft (<a2_0><b6_0><b7_0>5 to 6<a2_0/> m<b7_0/><b6_0/>) beneath the city without hitting water, which impedes <a3_0><b8_0>underground construction<b8_0/><a3_0/>, though some underground parking garages exist. For this reason, the mass transit systems in and around Miami are elevated or at-grade.[citation needed]
